title: 104_s1857
content: The "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996" establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices with specific duties. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996," is tasked with studying laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices. It will consider the amount of money spent on campaigns, disclosure of funds, the impact of current laws on qualified candidates seeking office, and the financing system for campaigns. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996," will study laws and regulations governing Federal campaign practices. This includes examining whether current laws encourage or discourage qualified candidates from seeking office, promoting trust in the political process, ensuring access to media for voters to be informed of candidates' positions, and addressing other relevant matters. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 9 private sector members appointed by various leaders, with a chairperson selected within 7 days. The Commission consists of 9 private sector members appointed by different leaders, with a chairperson selected within 7 days by majority vote. If the chairperson is not selected within 30 days, all current members will be discharged. After 7 days, if the chairperson position remains vacant, all current Commission members will be discharged. Vacancies will be filled as per original appointment method. Each member is entitled to daily pay equivalent to level V of the Executive Schedule for duties performed. The Commission members are entitled to daily pay equivalent to level V of the Executive Schedule for duties performed. Six members constitute a quorum, and decisions require the affirmative vote of 6 members. The Commission meets at the call of the chairperson or at the request of 6 members. SEC. 5. STAFF OF COMMISSION; SERVICES. The chairperson can appoint necessary staff without following certain appointment rules. SEC. 6. RECOMMENDATION; FAST TRACK PROCEDURES. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing the study conducted. The report may include recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns, agreed upon by 6 or more members. If 7 or more members agree on recommendations for campaign conduct changes, they can prepare bills for submission. The Commission may prepare bills for implementing recommendations on changes in campaign conduct if 7 or more members agree. These bills will receive expedited consideration by Congress, similar to trade agreement bills. The Commission will cease to exist 30 days after submitting the report. $750,000 is authorized for carrying out this Act.
